H0.text: Magma is the rock formed when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down, broken into small pieces, and those pieces pile up and are cemented together.

H1.text: Igneous is the classification of the new rock that forms when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down, broken into small pieces, piled up, and cemented together over time.

H2.text: Sedimentary is the classification of the new rock that forms when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down, broken into small pieces, piled up, and cemented together over time.

H3.text: Metamorphic is the classification of the new rock formed when dried lava from an old volcano is worn down and broken into small pieces, which then pile up and are cemented together.

A4.text: Volcanic tuff and volcanic breccias are formed by deposition and later cementation of lava fragments erupted by volcanoes.

A5.text: Sedimentary rocks are formed by the cementation of sediments, including particles from weathering and erosion of existing rocks or solidification of molten lava blobs erupted by volcanoes.
